replies.msg: 太貴了 下半季咁嘅表現
話說下年有咩人會清走 mejri走硬啦 澳洲佬 harris jj burke邊個會走

我屌牙
居然贏到 唔係tank嫁咩

今天血洗勇士拿下了久違的一勝，好在隔壁棚老鷹靠Trae Young絕殺鎖定勝利，兩隊勝差依然維持在3.5場。不過灰熊今天輸球，戰績和小牛並列聯盟到數第六。坦克之爭將進入白熱化。

老鷹接下來的賽程依序為
鵜鶘、拓荒者、公鹿、馬刺、76人、魔術、公鹿、溜馬

小牛接下來的賽程依序為
國王、熱火、雷霆、76人、灰狼、灰熊、灰熊、太陽、馬刺

灰熊接下來的賽程依序為
雷霆、勇士、太陽、快艇、拓荒者、小牛、小牛、活塞、勇士

老鷹之後的對手大多為季後賽球隊，但依照球隊近況來講或許能贏下當中的三、四場。但基本上老鷹應該不會拱手讓出兩個樂透籤的補強機會，所以小牛要坦到第五其實不太容易。

小牛若能維持今天的氣勢或許能在拿下幾場勝利，但面對灰熊的兩場比賽至關重要，若兩場皆以敗仗收場或許能保住倒數第六的席次，以37.2%抽中前四順位的機率來拼回首輪籤。

Dallas Mavericks: 5 best fits for the Mavs in the 2019 NBA Draft

The Dallas Mavericks must select in the top five to keep their first-round pick in the NBA Draft. Here is a look at the five players the Mavs should target.

The Dallas Mavericks are entering an exciting and possible franchise-altering offseason. Fans are hopeful that the pairing of soon-to-be Rookie of the Year Luka Doncic and former All-Star Kristaps Porzingis can lead the Mavs back to the playoffs. The rest of the roster is going to undergo some significant changes this summer, though.
The Mavericks have money to spend in free agency. Will they be able to sign a third star? Or does the front office add pieces to compliment Doncic and Porzingis? Leadership could also decide to sign players to short-term deals and try again in free agency in 2020. Mavs fans cannot wait to see what happens.
Keep their first rounder?

May 14 will be the first important date on the Mavericks offseason calendar. That night is the draft lottery. It will determine if Dallas keeps their 2019 first round pick. Remember the Mavs traded this year’s selection top-five protected to the Hawks to get Luka Doncic on draft night 2018.
Their record will place them outside the first five picks, so the Mavericks will need some luck to keep the choice. That also means Dallas cannot choose fifth. They would have to be selected in the lottery which is only the top four picks.
The draft takes place on June 20. Let us assume the selection remains with the Dallas Mavericks. Who are the players the Mavs should be targeting? Things can change with the combine and pre-draft workouts still ahead, but let us take a look at the five best fits for Dallas in the 2019 NBA Draft.

5. Jarrett Culver- SG- Texas Tech

The fight for inclusion on this list was fierce. Darius Garland is likely to be a top-five pick and has a tremendous amount of offensive upside as a point guard. The fit next to Luka and Kristaps did not seem right, though. There were plenty of other candidates, but ultimately Jarrett Culver could not be denied.
The Texas native led the Red Raiders to the NCAA Tournament finals. They ultimately lost an overtime heartbreaker, but the 20-year-old only improved his draft stock.
The 6’6 guard profiles as NBA-ready defender that can do some secondary playmaking. Culver averaged 18.6 points, 6.3 rebounds, 3.7 assists, 1.4 steals, 0.5 blocks, and 2.7 turnovers per game in 32.2 minutes a night over 37 games during his sophomore campaign at Texas Tech.
The Dallas Mavericks need to improve their perimeter defense, and Culver figures to help in that area. He is a career 34.8 percent 3-point shooter in his two seasons at Texas Tech. The Mavs will want him to improve that part of his game.
An offseason of drafting Jarrett Culver plus adding a strong perimeter defensive point guard and rebound gobbling center in free agency would put the Mavericks on the path to contention in 2020 and beyond.

4. De’Andre Hunter- SF/PF- Virginia

De’Andre Hunter led Virginia to the NCAA Championship in 2019. He had a massive title game scoring 27 points with nine rebounds, one assist, one steal, and four 3-pointers made. It capped off a fantastic run by the Cavaliers and vaulted Hunter firmly into the top five draft conversation.
He turns 22 in December which will scare off some teams, but he seems to fit on the Mavericks.
Hunter is a combo forward (listed at 6’7 and 225 lbs.) that can guard anyone on the floor and shoot the ball from anywhere on the court. He shot 52.1 percent from the field and 42.0 percent on his 3-pointers this season. Hunter is also an NBA-ready defender with the potential to become elite.
He is not a high-volume shooter. Hunter averaged 10.2 field goal attempts per game this season. The Dallas Mavericks have plenty of scoring with Doncicand Porzingis both projected to net 20-plus a night. Hunter would be asked to be a spot-up shooter and improve the Mavs defense. He is capable of both.
The major drawback would be Hunter’s rebounding. He only averaged 5.0 per game this season in 32.2 minutes a night. The Mavericks are a subpar rebounding team, and Porzingis does not gobble up rebounds for a big man. If they drafted Hunter, Luka Doncic would likely lead the Mavs in rebounding next season, and it could be an issue for the team all season.

replies.msg: 佢打ncaa決賽廢到冇腦傻鳩

3. R.J. Barrett- SG/SF- Duke

The top three players in the 2019 NBA Draft seem set at this point. R.J. Barrett may not be the best fit on the Dallas Mavericks, but he is the player to take at three. It is important to remember that a top three draft pick and the player chosen with it are tradeable commodities in the NBA. There is never a need to reach down this high in the draft because the team can trade back and gain additional assets.
Barrett is a 6’7 wing that plays his best basketball as the team’s primary ball-handler. He is a natural scorer (22.6 points per game at Duke) with better playmaking ability than his assist numbers show. The Dallas Mavericks have Luka filling that role. Barrett struggles with his perimeter shooting (30.8 percent 3-pointer shooter this season) and would not play as well off the ball.
He is also a fantastic rebounder. Barrett averaged 7.6 per game for Duke. He turns 19 in June and would help Dallas solve their problems on the glass.
The Dallas Mavericks may pick R.J. Barrett at three in the same way the Atlanta Hawks did with Luka Doncic. It is a wise selection because some rebuilding team would love to have Barrett, and the Mavs could trade back or get an established veteran to improve their team next season.

2. Ja Morant- PG- Murray State

Ja Morant had a breakout sophomore season at Murray State and vaulted himself into the likely number two overall pick. A year ago that sentence would have sounded crazy, but things change quickly on the draft prospect landscape.
Morant had a fantastic season. He averaged 24.5 points, 5.7 rebounds, 10.0 assists, 1.8 steals, 1.7 3-pointers made, 0.8 blocks, and 5.2 turnovers per game in 36.6 minutes a night. Morant shot 49.9 percent from the field, 36.3 percent on his 3-pointers, and 81.3 percent from the free throw line.The fit in Dallas may not sound ideal but could work wonderfully assuming Morant can do two specific things. He needs to be able to space the floor and play average to above perimeter defense. Morant can do the first, but the second would be a massive question mark.
The Mavericks need a point guard this summer. Not one that dominates the ball because they have Luka as their primary ball handler. They need a point guard that can defend the elite guards in the Western Conference. Ja Morant may not fit that bill, but his talent is too good to pass up with the second overall pick. Expect him to be in contention for Rookie of the Year in 365 days.

1. Zion Williamson- PF- Duke

Zion Williamson topping the list should not be a surprise. No matter what team wins the lottery and has the first pick, they should draft Zion. He has superstar upside and elite athletic ability. Williamson combination of strength and explosiveness are difficult to match.
Fans have seen the highlights all season as well. He is going to be a fun player to watch as a rookie. Expect plenty of Zion dunks and blocked shots filling the top ten’s next season.
A frontcourt of Williamson and Kristaps Porzingiswould be entertaining. Zion is not a fantastic shooter (33.8 percent on his 3-pointers at Duke), but Porzingis can space the floor. That would allow Williamson to operate down low where he excels.
On the defensive end, they also complement each other. Williamson can be the rebounder (8.9 per game this season) and Porzingis the rim protector. Zion did average 1.8 blocks per game for Duke. He can also protect the rim, but not as well as the 7’3 Porzingis.
Williamson also averaged 22.6 points per game and 2.1 assists in 30.0 minutes a night. He can score and do some playmaking for a big man.
Dallas Mavericks fans would be jumping out of their chairs on May 14 if they win the lottery. That would mean the shot at drafting Zion Williamson. The Mavericks could also attempt to swap the pick for a third All-Star talent to vault them into title contention next season.
